#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Buy Crafts from Third World Countries
#Text=Countries across the world craft objects , jewelry , furniture and more based on their own customs , culture and history .
#Text=If you are interested in buying crafts from a country different from your own , then you have a number of options in your town and across the world .
#Text=You may also choose to buy crafts from third world countries in order to support fair trade .
#Text=Buying fair trade crafts helps to prevent low wages and unfair working conditions .
#Text=There are some guidelines you should follow to ensure you are buying from a country that is benefiting from your purchase .
#Text=You may need to do a little Internet research to ensure you are buying the crafts you prefer .
#Text=Read on to find out how to buy crafts from third world countries .
#Text=Steps
#Text=Research fair trade organizations .
#Text=There are a number of non-profit companies that choose to keep consumers up to date about fair trade options .
#Text=These include fairtraderesource.org , chfinternational.org , and fair trade organizations of specific countries , such as fta.org.au .
#Text=Decide if you want to buy crafts from a specific country .
#Text=For example , you may admire the bamboo furniture from Malaysia or carvings from Africa .
#Text=Search for a non-profit organization that tells you where to find shops that sell that country 's goods .
#Text=For example , there is a Bangladesh cooperative that represents 60,000 artisans .
#Text=Go to eBay or Overstock .
#Text=Both of these websites have acquired companies that previously sought to promote fair trade crafts .
#Text=Ebay acquired World of Good , and you can buy handcrafted gifts from third world countries at worldofgood.ebay.com .
#Text=Overstock.com provides a fair trade site , called overstock.com/Worldstock-Fair-Trade .
#Text=You can find anything from jewelry to furniture and more .
#Text=Search for local stores that specialize in fair trade crafts .
#Text=Most mid to large-sized cities have a few fair trade stores .
#Text=You can often find the stories behind the manufacturers of the crafts .
#Text=Ask the store how they acquired the crafts .
#Text=The best way to tell if you are buying from a certified fair trade , third world craft carrier is to ask how the crafts were acquired .
#Text=Visit world craft museums , such as The Museum of Craft and Folk Art or the Museum of Craft and Design in San Francisco .
#Text=These museums fill their gift shops with crafts that are well-crafted and distinctive .
#Text=Check the museum websites for crafts that can be bought online .
#Text=Visit summer markets in your town .
#Text=People who have emigrated from other countries often stock booths filled with their home country 's crafts .
#Text=Peruvian alpaca crafts are common at summer craft markets .
#Text=Visit a third world country and buy the crafts straight from the source .
#Text=While this is the most expensive option , it is the best way to ensure you are buying straight from a craftsman .
#Text=Research craft workshops where you can visit and buy directly after viewing the creation of the crafts .
#Text=For example , in St. Kitts there is a batik factory where the batiks are made and then sold .
#Text=In Peru , you can visit an alpaca farm where yarn is created , died , woven and sold .
#Text=Things You 'll Need
#Text=Summer markets
#Text=Internet research
#Text=Fair trade shops
#Text=Trip abroad
